name: Fallopian tube
description: The fallopian tubes (oviducts) transport the ovum from ovary to uterus. The mucosa has elaborate longitudinal folds (plicae) most prominent in the ampulla.

features: Simple columnar epithelium (Ciliated cells + Peg cells)
Peg cells: Non-ciliated, secretory (nutrient rich fluid)
theory.examTips: Looks like a 'labyrinth' of mucosal folds. Epithelium is simple columnar but looks messy due to ciliated vs secretory cells. Ampulla has MOST folds, Isthmus has FEWER folds and THICKER muscle.

name: Ovary
description: The ovary is the female gonad, consisting of a cortex (with ovarian follicles) and a vascular medulla, covered by simple cuboidal 'germinal' epithelium.

features: Tunica Albuginea: Dense CT underlying epithelium
Cortex: Contains follicles in various stages (Primordial, Primary, Secondary, Graafian)
Corpus Luteum: Large, folded, endocrine gland (Granulosa lutein & Theca lutein cells)
Medulla: Loose CT with large blood vessels (Helicine arteries)
location: Attached to broad ligament by mesovarium
theory.examTips: Identify follicles! Primordial = Squamous cells. Primary = Cuboidal cells. Secondary = Antrum forms. Graafian = Huge antrum + Cumulus oophorus. Corpus Luteum looks like a large, folded, eosinophilic mass (endocrine).

name: Uterus
description: The uterus consists of Endometrium (mucosa), Myometrium (thick smooth muscle), and Perimetrium (serosa). The endometrium undergoes cyclic changes.

features: Endometrium: Simple columnar epithelium + Tubular glands + Stroma
Myometrium: Thick bundles of smooth muscle (interlacing)
Proliferative Phase: Straight glands, mitotic figures
Secretory Phase: Saw-toothed/coiled glands, secretions in lumen
function: Site of implantation and fetal development
theory.examTips: Endometrium changes! Proliferative = Test tube glands. Secretory = Saw-tooth/Corkscrew glands. Myometrium is massive and vascular (arcuate arteries in stratum vasculare).
